topics.title: Communication as agency and self-reflection
topics.summary: Wes argues that confusion, skepticism, or apathy often stems from how operators explain things, and encourages taking responsibility for improving clarity, compellingness, and anticipating questions. Communication is framed as a learnable skill that increases the odds of getting desired outcomes.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for WorkOS (enterprise auth/authorization) and Vanta (security/compliance automation).

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Wes, shares testimonials about her communication impact, and sets the episode goal: practical tactics for executive communication and influence. Wes adds the idea of “practice like it’s game day” by treating every stakeholder interaction as reps, not just exec presentations.

topics.title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in first
topics.summary: Wes explains the common mistake of jumping into implementation details before the audience agrees the idea is worth doing. She shares a concrete example (weekly wins collection) and how a brief upfront “why/benefit” framing plus a clear ask prevents crickets and back-and-forth.

topics.title: Being concise: clarity requires preparation
topics.summary: Concision is defined as density of insight, not shortness. Wes argues the real bottleneck is not knowing the core point, and recommends lightweight prep before meetings (purpose, desired outcome, key points) to avoid rambling and improve executive-level communication.

topics.title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load
topics.summary: Wes recommends rereading before sending, explicitly asking “how can I reduce cognitive load,” and trimming secondary material. She introduces the “blast radius” idea: a confusing Slack/memo creates costly back-and-forth across many readers, so small upfront edits create outsized leverage.

topics.title: Signposting and avoiding excessive formatting
topics.summary: Wes describes signposting words/phrases (e.g., “because,” “for example,” “next step,” “first/second/third”) to guide readers and listeners through structure. She cautions against over-bolding and over-bulleting, arguing fragments can hide unclear thinking and increase reader interpretation burden.

topics.title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
topics.summary: Wes suggests a first-principles feedback loop: track how quickly and smoothly you get the reaction/outcome you want, and iterate. She recommends experimenting like a game, but adopting one tactic at a time to avoid overwhelm and build habits.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda (all-in-one collaborative workspace for docs, spreadsheets, workflows, and AI).

topics.title: Slack writing standards and compounding leverage
topics.summary: Lenny shares an anecdote about Wes’s high-quality Slack messages (complete sentences, punctuation, clear takeaways) and Wes connects better communication to faster responses and better reception of ideas. They emphasize small upfront investments that compound across teams and time.

topics.title: Calibrating confidence: speak accurately about certainty
topics.summary: Wes explains pitfalls of overconfidence (presenting hypotheses as facts) and underconfidence (over-disclaiming strong recommendations). The solution is precise language about conviction level, plus sharing reasoning/evidence so others can align or challenge specific assumptions.
